awd_titl_txt: Integrating Computational Thinking in Ecosystem Science Education via Modeling in Immersive Virtual Worlds
awd_abstract_narration:
Research has revealed that young students can reason and understand complex science concepts and can engage at relatively sophisticated levels in computer programming. Developing scientific and computational understanding depends upon a strong foundation in elementary school, thus, this project will introduce third grade students to computational thinking (abstraction, data representation, and algorithms), computer modeling, and environmental systems thinking through an interdisciplinary, virtual reality curriculum on ecosystems. The curriculum will scaffold student understanding of computational modeling as a core practice used to explore and understand ecosystem interactions, such as the interconnection of habitats within an ecosystem and species survival. Integrating computer modeling in the elementary science curriculum advances important 21st century learning goals regarding computational thinking within disciplinary contexts. The design-based research will investigate the seamless integration of life science, mathematics, and computing to improve both student learning and teaching and will contribute substantially to advancing elementary science, technology, mathematics, and computing education that will reveal important aspects of children's understanding of complex environmental and computational thinking concepts. This project is funded by the STEM+Computing Partnership (STEM+C) program that seeks to advance multidisciplinary integration of computing and computational thinking in STEM teaching and learning through applied research and development across one or more domains; advancement of computing in K-12; and broadening participation in computing fields. Investments are made in critical areas of pedagogy, pre-service education, and in-service teacher professional development.   

The project will use design-based research to combine an immersive virtual environment with hands-on interactive modeling through a scaffolded computational interface that will connect visual models to dynamic representations of ecosystem interactions in a simulated forest setting. The curriculum will provide a supported, object-oriented programming environment (similar to Scratch and StarLogo NOVA) with a simple, scaffolded block interface customized to focus on ecosystems modeling, and designed specifically for younger children. The learning goals related to the study of habitats and food webs are taught using a systems perspective, shifting the instructional focus from comprehension of static representations to consequential student interaction with dynamic computational models. The project will investigate which approaches to abstraction and representation offer the best scaffolding to young students and to what extent students are able to construct, modify, and interpret computational models of ecological concepts; to what extent do students show gains in understanding of causal dynamics in ecosystem science; and how teachers can best incorporate an interdisciplinary science and computing curricula in their practice. Project outcomes will inform how to best integrate science content, science inquiry, computational modeling processes, and computational thinking, which are core objectives of the STEM+Computing program.

Project Outcomes

This award resulted in the development and study of a technology-based curriculum for elementary school students called EcoMOD. The EcoMOD curriculum interweaves an immersive 3D virtual ecosystem and a 2D visual programming and modeling environment to support learning both ecosystem science concepts and computational modeling.

Starting in elementary grades, it is important for students to learn science practices, and also how computational thinking and programming is integral to science. One important use of computational thinking in science is in the construction of computational models ? computer programs that can simulate scientific phenomena. Models can help students develop questions and explanations, make predictions, and express their ideas. Programming computational models can be difficult, but visual block-based programming interfaces offer new opportunities to bring computational modeling for science learning to elementary school.

EcoMOD is a 14-day 3rd grade science curriculum focused on a forest ecosystem, and the behaviors and causal interactions of two keystone species: beavers and woodpeckers. The software includes two computational tools; a 3D immersive virtual world and a 2D modeling tool. In the 3D world (Figure 1), students explore a realistic virtual forest ecosystem. They can move around, observe animal behavior, collect data, and travel in time. The 3D world also includes a point-of-view (POV) tool (Figure 2) that gives students the opportunity to experience the 3D ecosystem from an animal?s perspective, learning to ?be? a beaver or woodpecker.

The 2D modeling tool supports computational modeling activities, as students program an agent-based model of a beaver building a dam (Figure 3). Coding is done with customized programming blocks to direct the beaver?s behavior, such as ?move toward tree,? ?bite tree,? and ?pick up log.? Students engage in coding over several days to build and test their beaver model. Model outcomes are visible in a 2D sandbox that includes a simplified representation of the beaver, as well as other animals such as mallards and trout. As students watch their beaver agent go through the steps of building a dam, they can see changes in the other elements of the ecosystem. Graphs allow students to view the emergent outcomes of their models as the dam is built; e.g., the mallard population increases, but trout decrease (Figure 4).

At three key points during the curriculum, as students generate new understandings about ecosystem relationships, they draw causal concept maps that represent the complex relationships within and among the different organisms and features of the ecosystem (Figure 5).

Findings

The EcoMOD curriculum was implemented in March-June 2019 with teachers and 8 classrooms of 3rd and 4th grade students (approx. 150 students). Data collection included pre-post surveys, classroom observations and video, logfiles, student artifacts, and teacher interviews and surveys. Students showed growth in both content and practices, specifically in developing ecosystems science content, causal reasoning and computational modeling.

As students built and tested their computational models, they interpreted the outcomes of their model by observing agent interactions within the 2D sandbox and by drawing and interpreting graphs of change over time. Students compared the outcomes with observations and data they collected while in the 3D virtual environment, and used both representations to make connections and learn about causal relationships in the ecosystem.

Student explanations and representations of the ecosystem through concept mapping were significantly more detailed and expressed deeper understanding of causal mechanisms by the end of curriculum, and incorporated learning from both the immersive 3D world and their computational modeling activities. Students also developed programming skills; understanding of computational constructs such as sequencing, loops, and conditionals was more sophisticated by the end of the curriculum.

 

Teachers reported that the curriculum was highly feasible and appreciated the structure and content of the lesson plans and materials Student were highly engaged, and teachers felt that the curriculum supported students in inquiry-based learning, science content, causality, and coding. Some teachers expressed surprise at all of the connections their students were able to make, particularly with regard to the causal maps and coding.

Impact

EcoMOD findings demonstrate the feasibility of curricula that integrate an immersive authentic simulation with a subject-specific computational modeling environment. Elementary age students, when provided with appropriate scaffolding, are capable of learning complex causal dynamics. The curriculum provides a promising pathway for supporting the integration of science and computing within the elementary grades by situating computing within a familiar and accessible context and providing a rich computational environment for students (and teachers) to construct and test computational models.

Developing advanced scientific and computational knowledge in later grades depends on creating a strong foundation in the elementary school. EcoMOD offers practitioners an effective approach for integrating computational modeling, science content, and inquiry-based practices within elementary science instruction and demonstrates the impact of immersive learning technologies and agent-based modeling in classroom settings to increase knowledge and interest in STEM.
